But your bright line rule... I just want to be sure I understand it... would cover the operation of a commercial activity, not just working for the government.

If they ran a casino, for example, in Indian company... country, even though it's on a reservation, but as long as it's in Indian country, that... the bright line rule would protect the income from the casino--

turn.speaker: g_william_rice
turn.label: Mr. G. William Rice
turn.text: That's exactly right.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --or discover an oil well or something like that.

turn.speaker: g_william_rice
turn.label: Mr. G. William Rice
turn.text: That's exactly right.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: g_william_rice
turn.label: Mr. G. William Rice
turn.text: If it's the Indian conduct in the Indian country, then that is what Congress has put behind the law.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But if the tribe is running a business off... out of Indian country, I suppose Mescalero controls.

turn.speaker: g_william_rice
turn.label: Mr. G. William Rice
turn.text: That would be Mescalero.

If the tribe chose to take the business 100 miles away from its Indian country, and the United States does not put that in trust or does not otherwise take action that would make it Indian country, then that's subject to State jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Suppose the Indian... suppose the reservation... even if the reservation wasn't formally abolished, all of the land, other than that which has been held in trust and allotted to Indians, all of that has already been patented to non-Indians or to somebody else.

turn.speaker: g_william_rice
turn.label: Mr. G. William Rice
turn.text: True.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So, it would be... you might say, well, here's where the reservation used to be, but there's--

turn.speaker: g_william_rice
turn.label: Mr. G. William Rice
turn.text: Well, there's still a real solid Indian presence in that area, and I think we've taken the position in--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --Well, I know, but you wouldn't say that you could exclude anybody you wanted to any... within the bounds of the old reservation now.

turn.speaker: g_william_rice
turn.label: Mr. G. William Rice
turn.text: --Well, no, I wouldn't say that we would exclude the landowners, no.
I think that one is solved in Montana v. the United States--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: g_william_rice
turn.label: Mr. G. William Rice
turn.text: --and a couple of other cases.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: g_william_rice
turn.label: Mr. G. William Rice
turn.text: The difference, though, with the Indian conduct in those areas that have still retained reservation status is Mattz v. Arnett, and those cases say that the Indian work... the Indian activity there, their actions, are still within the Indian country.
I think I want to make it very clear that our position in the brief and here also is that there's three fallback positions basically on the Indian country issue.
One of those is... and the first one I think is that the original boundaries are still there.
The second one is that regardless... if you read the allotment agreement and the legislative history, which is in the exhibits that were in the Tenth Circuit--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But--

turn.speaker: g_william_rice
turn.label: Mr. G. William Rice
turn.text: --we've got a diminished one, not a big one.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --But if the reservation were still there and was not abolished, you wouldn't say that every acre of ground within the bounds of the reservation would be Indian country.

turn.speaker: g_william_rice
turn.label: Mr. G. William Rice
turn.text: Yes, sir, it is Indian country because 1151(a) says that it includes all Indian reservations notwithstanding the issuance of any patent, and Seymour v. Superintendent says a patent to anybody, whether that's a patent to an Indian or a patent to a non-Indian.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Rice.
The case is submitted.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The honorable court is now adjourned until tomorrow at ten o'clock.
